texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I wrote about  installing Linux on the Lenovo ThinkPad T490 last month  and one of the biggest challenges was getting graphics working properly. The T490 comes with an option where you can get a discrete Nvidia MX250 GPU and it packs plenty of power in a small footprint.
texts.text: I wrote about  installing Linux on the Lenovo ThinkPad T490 last month  and one of the biggest challenges was getting graphics working properly. The T490 comes with an option where you can get a discrete Nvidia MX250 GPU and it packs plenty of power in a small footprint.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It also brings along a few issues.

texts.orig: Awful battery life
texts.text: Awful battery life

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are many times where it would be helpful to fully disable the Nvidia card to extend battery life when graphics processing is not needed. The MX250 is a Pascal family GPU and those GPUs require signed drivers, so nouveau will not work.
texts.text: There are many times where it would be helpful to fully disable the Nvidia card to extend battery life when graphics processing is not needed. The MX250 is a Pascal family GPU and those GPUs require signed drivers, so nouveau will not work.

texts.label: paragraph

texts.text: There is a handy kernel feature called  VGA Switcheroo   (yes, that is the name) . It gives you a quick method for turning the GPU on and off. Unfortunately, that does require the nouveau module to work with the card.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Suspend and resume
texts.text: Suspend and resume

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are issues with suspend and resume with the Nvidia drivers after Linux 4.8. If you close the lid on the laptop, the laptop suspends properly and you can see the pulsating LED light on the lid.
texts.text: There are issues with suspend and resume with the Nvidia drivers after Linux 4.8. If you close the lid on the laptop, the laptop suspends properly and you can see the pulsating LED light on the lid.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Open the lid after a few seconds and you will see a black screen (possibly with a kernel trace) that looks like this:
texts.text: Open the lid after a few seconds and you will see a black screen (possibly with a kernel trace) that looks like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[   51.435212] ACPI: Waking up from system sleep state S3
[   51.517986] ACPI: EC: interrupt unblocked
[   51.567244] nvidia 0000:2d:00.0: Refused to change power state, currently in D3
texts.text:
[   51.435212] ACPI: Waking up from system sleep state S3
[   51.517986] ACPI: EC: interrupt unblocked
[   51.567244] nvidia 0000:2d:00.0: Refused to change power state, currently in D3

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The laptop will lock up and the fans will spin up shortly after. The only remedy is a hard power off.
texts.text: The laptop will lock up and the fans will spin up shortly after. The only remedy is a hard power off.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is related to a Nvidia driver bug that surfaced after Linux 4.8 added per-port PCIe power management . That feature allows the kernels to handle PCIe power management for each port individually. It helps certain PCIe devies (or portions of those devices) to go into various power saving modes independently.
texts.text: This is related to a Nvidia driver bug that surfaced after Linux 4.8 added per-port PCIe power management . That feature allows the kernels to handle PCIe power management for each port individually. It helps certain PCIe devies (or portions of those devices) to go into various power saving modes independently.

texts.orig: Digging deep
texts.text: Digging deep

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you can't control your hardware well enough in the OS, and you can control it in the BIOS, the only option remaining is to examine your ACPI tables. This requires dumping the DSDT and SSDT tables from the laptop. These tables provide a map of instructions for taking all kinds of actions with the hardware on the laptop, including turning devices on and off.
texts.text: If you can't control your hardware well enough in the OS, and you can control it in the BIOS, the only option remaining is to examine your ACPI tables. This requires dumping the DSDT and SSDT tables from the laptop. These tables provide a map of instructions for taking all kinds of actions with the hardware on the laptop, including turning devices on and off.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🔥  DISCLAIMER: Tinkering with DSDT and SSDT files can damage your machine if you are not familiar with the process. All changes in these files must be made with extreme care and you should try the  smallest  possible change first to reduce the risks.
texts.text: 🔥  DISCLAIMER: Tinkering with DSDT and SSDT files can damage your machine if you are not familiar with the process. All changes in these files must be made with extreme care and you should try the  smallest  possible change first to reduce the risks.
